Yaa A. is 32 and single with no children. She lives with her family in Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and sells banku with soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. She has many customers since it is enjoyed by many Ghanaians as breakfast, lunch and supper.

She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to raise business income to include the sale of cereals in bags to her customers. Yaa has employed workers who assist her in her local food joint. She has been in business for three years now. She belongs to the village bank called "Promise."

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana P. is 31 years old. She is divorced and has given birth to two children, a male and a female. She says her children are in junior high and primary school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. It is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region.

Juliana is a seamstress by profession. She doesn't have her own workshop and as a result, is currently working in her house. She says she has no apprentice for now. Juliana wants a loan to buy some working patterns and fabrics to sew more designs for sale. Juliana has been in business for four years. She is hoping to acquire her own workshop and give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy fabrics and sewing materials

loans.name: Dionisio Rafael

texts.es: El Señor Dionisio Rafael M. tiene la edad de 58 años, su estado civil es casado. Don Dionisio tiene 7 hijos y todos trabajan. La actividad económica de Dionisio es el servicio de electricidad. Hace más de 20 años que se dedica a este negocio. Dionicio inicio con este oficio  porque laboraba en una empresa energía, por lo que su trabajo es muy peligroso pero como no tenía muchas opciones de trabajo y decidió prestar los servicios de electricista. Por lo que los financiamientos le han servido de mucha ayuda por que solo así ha comprado las herramientas necesarias para sus trabajos. El solicita este dinero para la compra de alicates, alambres y otros materiales especiales para su trabajo. su sueño es seguir con vida ya que este trabajo es muy peligroso.
texts.en:
Señor Dionisio Rafael M. is 58 years old and married. Don Dionisio has 7 children, all of whom are working. Don Dionisio's has worked as an electrician for more than 20 years. He began in this business because he previously worked for an energy company. His work is very dangerous, but as he did not have many options for employment, he decided to provide services as an electrician. Financing has helped him greatly, because he could not have purchased the tools he needed for this work without these loans. Don Dionisio is requesting this loan in order to purchase pincers, wires and other special materials for his work. His dream is to continue living, since this work is very dangerous.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Married with six children, Mary A. is currently taking care of five in school. Mary is a 36-year-old petty trader. She believes in hard work and dedication as the primary antidotes for minimizing poverty, and for that matter, she is very serious with her business. She trades in foodstuffs like plantains.

She started this business six years ago to take care of her home. She wants to use the loan to buy a larger supply of plantains to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country. She takes stock from the surrounding villages and retails it to her customers at retail prices. This, she said. should enable her to save more to help her husband support the family. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Promise’.

loans.use: To buy larger supply of plantains

loans.name: Kwakye

texts.en:
Kwakye A. is forty -five years old. He is married and has six children. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region.

Kwakye says his children are in junior high and primary school. His wife is a petty trader. He is also a petty trader. He runs a cold store in his community. Kwakye says his cold store is located at the market square. He sells fresh fish, beef, chicken, turkey, etc. He wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase his stock. Kwakye has been in business for two years. He is hopeful to expand his business and improve his standard of living. He is hopeful to give his children a sound education.

loans.use: To procure fresh fish and meat

loans.name: Kwame

texts.en:
Kwame A. is 40 years old; he is married and has two children. Both his children are currently in school. Kwame is very popular guy in his area because of his hard work and his dedication to work. He is a commercial driver. He is been driving for nine years now to support his family. He is hired by customers who need to get their goods to their various destinations and he charges them a reasonable rate.

Kwame's vehicle has developed a problem, making it very difficult to earn a living. He requests a loan to buy vehicle parts to maintain his van. Notwithstanding that, he wants to get a bigger truck; this, he believes, would help him achieve his dream. With the loan he wants to change the engine and his diesel tank, and weld other parts that are wearing out. He will be grateful for your assistance, he said. He belongs to the village bank called ‘Promise’.

loans.use: to maintain his truck van and for the purchase of new car

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian A. started her fish sales ten years ago at Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo of Ghana. Vivian prepares and serves her customers very tasty and good quality fish, and because of that many customers buy from her stand. She has a cunning mouth to convince her suppliers to sell her more fish when there is high demand for fish and the supply is low.

She buys stocks of fish from the fishermen and smokes them at a nearby stand. She has a big customer base that travels from the other part of the region to buy her fish. They buy from her both the fresh ones and the smoked ones. She is now 38 years old, married, and mother of six children. Currently all her children are in school. She wants to use the loan to buy increased stocks of assorted fish to make increased sales and income to support her children's educational needs and her business growth. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Provident’.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fish and dried fish

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John K. is thirty years old. He is married and has three children, one daughter and two sons. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. Kofiase is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region.

Kwabena says his children are currently in junior high and primary school. His wife is a food vendor. Kwabena is a petty trader. He runs a cold store in his community. Kwabena says his cold store is located on the street. He sells all kinds of fresh fish, beef, chicken, turkey, etc. He wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase his stock. Kwabena has been in business for two years. He is hopeful to expand his business and improve his standard of living. Kwabena is hopeful to give his children a sound education.

loans.use: To procure fresh fish and meat

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth H. is married and has three kids. She lives with her family at Dorma in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She is 29 years old. She runs a clothing shop and sells jeans, blouses and skirts, women's slippers and dressing bags for the past four years.

Elizabeth is constrained by lack of funds to run the business appropriately. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will help her to be more resourced to purchase good quality and large quantity to upgrade her inventory. She says she would be grateful for your assistance, and she belongs to a village bank called ‘Promise’.

loans.use: To purchase jeans, ladies' wear, and slippers

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is a resident of Purok (district) Namnama Magsaysay, Naguillan, Isabela. She is 43 years old and is married to a farmer named Victor Rossel. They are blessed with three children; Marjorie, the eldest, is 20 years old and presently studying in college, Jenny Rose is 18 years old and is also studying in college, finally Victor M. Jr., is 16 years old and will graduate from high school next year. As a mother who dreams of all of her children finishing their studies, Marites will do everything to provide for their needs. Their studies are her priority, and she is willing to sacrifice to reach their goals in life, for she believes their goals are also her goals and that their success someday will also be her success.

Marites sells snacks she cooks, like “pansit,” out of her snack house in her village. Sometimes, she also sells house to house and fortunately she is generating an income sufficient to sustain their daily needs. She is again hoping for a loan of PHP 5,000. This little amount will provide the capital she needs in her business. Marites hopes that she will manage to continuously support the financial needs of her two children who are studying in college. Their tuition fees are very high and she is really working hard just to pay their tuition fees and provide them their daily allowances. Through patience, Marites believe, she will overcome the hardship of life.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Maria Del Rosario

texts.es: María del Rosario R. C. tiene la edad de 29 años, su estado civil es casada. Doña María tiene 2 hijos y todos estudian. La actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. María es una mujer muy emprendedora y por muy sencillo que sea su trabajo, es el que mas le gusta ya que muchos de sus clientes son niños. Los propósitos de María son de invertir cada día en su pulpería par que sus clientes no se desanimen. Por los financiamientos es que su negocio ha mejorado y realmente ha visto el cambio. Y así recurre a Fundación León 2000 con el deseo de que le ayuden con el capital de trabajo y así comprara productos como golosinas, gaseosas, pan y jugos. Sus sueños son que la ayuda que se recibe de las organizaciones amigas esté ayudando a las personas que realmente lo necesitan.
texts.en:
María del Rosario R. C. is 29 years old and married. She has 2 school-age children. Her business is a bodega, which she has run for more than 5 years. María is a very enterprising woman, and as simple as her work is, it is what she loves best, since many of her customers are children. Maria intends to invest each day in her bodega so that her customers are not discouraged. She is requesting financing because her business has grown and the change is visible. Therefore, she came back to the Fundación León 2000 hoping to receive assistance with working capital, for the purchase of sweets, sodas, bread and juice. Her dream is that the help she receives from friendly organizations will also help those people who really need it.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Amitié Plus Group

texts.fr: Constant Nsotala fabrique des cakes et des gâteaux qu’il vend dans son quartier situé à l’ouest de Kinshasa. A coté de cette fabrication, il est entrain de développer une petite boutique d’articles divers sollicités par beaucoup de gens. Il a planifié d’acheter avec le crédit de ce mois de mai des produits recherchés par sa clientèle tels que des savons, du sucre, des conserves, etc…dans le souci de renforcer son capital et accroitre le revenu. Constant est menuisier de formation mais il est content d’exercer ce commerce car ca lui procure des moyens financiers pour supporter sa famille. Il a commencé son commerce en vendant du maїs et du manioc en 1996 avec un capital initial de $25. En 2003, au bout d’un dur travail, de la détermination et surtout d’une bonne gestion, il est parvenu à atteindre un capital de $600. C’est ce montant qui lui a permis d’acheter deux fours d’occasion de fabrication des gâteaux. Actuellement, son capital est de $270 et son activité génère un bénéfice de $120 par mois. Son ambition est d’ouvrir un jour une boulangerie car la demande est très grande. Constant est mieux connu dans son milieu à cause de la qualité des ses produits. Il est marié et père de 2 enfants âgés entre 10 et 14 ans. Tous deux vont à l’école.
texts.en:
Constant Nsotala makes cookies and cakes that he sells in his neighborhood, located in the western part of Kinshasa. In addition, he's developing a small shop selling various commonly used items. He plans to use this loan to buy products his clientele is asking for, such as soaps, sugar, canned food, etc... in order to bolster his working capital and increase his revenue. Constant is a trained furniture maker, but he's happy to run this business because it provides him with financial means to support his family. He started his business in 1996 with an initial capital of $25, selling corn and cassava. In 2003, after years of hard work, determination, and, most importantly, good management, he succeeded in achieving a $600 capital. This amount enabled him to buy two used ovens to cook cookies. His capital now amounts to $270, and his business turns a monthly profit of $120. His ambition is to one day open a bakery, because demand for it is very high. Constant is well known in his field, thanks to the quality of his products. He's married and the father of 2 children, age 10 and 14, who both attend school.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 5 boxes of soap, 1 sack of sugar, and canned food

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina A. is 31 years old; she is widowed and mother of two children. One is in school whilest the younger is still crawling. Augustina lives at Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She is in the sale of foodstuffs in the community market. She sells items like cooking oil, tinned tomatoes, bags of rice, vegetables, etc. Selling these products is good, she says, because they move very fast and you can easily recover your money quickly. She takes delivery of goods from the surrounding villages and Kumasi.

Augustina deals directly with the wholesalers rather than retailers who would sell to her at a high price. She has sixteen years selling experience in foodstuffs. She is requesting the loan to buy more goods to help her provide for the family. She believes this can be possible with the help of loan assistance. Therefore she wants the loan to buy more bags of raw materials like rice, spices, tinned tomatoes, and fresh vegetables. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Trust in Jesus’.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs like cooking oil, bags of rice, spices and tinned tomatoes, etc.

loans.name: Collins

texts.en:
Collins K. is 27 years old. He is single and lives in his one-room apartment with his younger brother. He sells used footwear like slippers, sandals, shoes, and sometimes school bags. Collins has been in business for the last six years. He sells his products through hawking; he normally treks to sell in villages during their market days. Depending upon the amount of his goods, he employs up to three young boys who assist him in selling.

He needs the loan to enable him to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. He believes the loan will help him to be more resourced to purchase good quality and large quantity to upgrade his inventory. With the loan, he wants to purchase assorted used shoes, sandals and slippers in bulk. He would be grateful for your assistance, and he belongs to the village bank called ‘House of faith’.

loans.use: To purchase used shoes, slippers, and sandals etc.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana A. is a 50-year-old trader. She is widowed with five children; one of them is currently schooling whilest the rest are working. She has been selling used clothes in the local market of Dorma for four years. She sometimes adds cloth to the used clothing.

With the income from her business, Esther supports all her kids. Her major business challenge over the years has to do with funds to scale up the business. She has lots of marketing experience and is very confident that the loan would enable her to achieve remarkable business progress. She wants to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothes and cloth to serve her customers. She hopes to save enough to pay for her one child's complete schooling. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Abotre,’ which means patience.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Mycel

texts.en:
“Patience and hard work is the key to the attainment of anyone’s goals” said Mycel E. of Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte in Nueva Vizcaya. Mycel got married at the age of 20; unfortunately, she is already separated from her husband.  Mycel did not lose hope and continues with her life. 

She is engaged in the buying and selling of vegetables and is a dealer of AVON products. Mycel is asking for a loan amounting to PHP14,000 as additional working capital in both of her businesses. She is hoping that her business will grow towards a better life.

loans.use: Business capital

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Serafina

texts.en:
Serafina and Braulio T. are a couple who live in a rural place located in Barangay Monguia, Dupax Del Norte of Nueva Vizcaya. They were blessed with five children. Some of her children were still studying, while others could no longer continue their education due to a lack of livelihood resources. She believes with her patience and sacrifices, she can improve her business and send her children to college.

Her husband tills their rice field and plants vegetables along with other root crops. Serafina vends snacks to help her husband earn for a daily income. She also sometimes sells vegetables in order to increase her business income. She is hoping to borrow a loan from lenders amounting to PHP10,000 in order to have additional working capital to improve her business. She is so thankful that she earns an average of PHP800 weekly. This is already a big help, lessening the burden of providing for her family daily needs.

loans.use: Business Capital

location.town: Monguia, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Felicia N. is 42 years old, married, and mother of four children who are currently in school. She lives in Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. 

To support her household, she buys and sells cosmetics to loyal clients in her neighborhood. She says selling cosmetics is very lucrative thus she wants to expand her inventory. Felicia walks very long distances to make sales,  sometimes having to hire a car to carry her goods. She is asking for your assistance to buy more cartons of cosmetics to increase her sales, earn a good income, and meet her family’s needs. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Yewoha Nhyira’ which means Jehovah’s Blessing.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of cosmetics

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella Y. is 30-year-old mother with a child who is going to start school. She believes hard work and dedication are the primary antidotes to minimize poverty. As such, she is very serious with her business. Stella has been very resourceful to her family.

Four years ago, Stella started a business of trading food stuff, like plantain. Her major market is the greater Accra of Ghana.  She would like a loan to buy a larger supply of plantains to serve her customers throughout the season. In the face of increasing prices due to the current food crisis in the country, she believes a loan can help her buy bulk plantain from farmers to eliminate the high prices from middlemen. Stella belongs to a village bank called ‘Yewoha Nhyira’ that means Jehovah’s Blessing.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of plantain

loans.name: Jenny Elizabeth

texts.es: Jenny Elizabeth Alegría R. tiene la edad de 39 años, su estado civil es casada. Doña Jenny tiene 4 hijos. La actividad económica es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más 12 años que se dedica a este negocio. Doña Jenny inicio este negocio por una tía, que le enseño el oficio y fue así como le gusto este negocio además  le ayudaba con la manutención de su familia. Los propósitos de Jenny son de seguir creciendo con su negocio para predominar fuertemente en el mercado. El dinero solicitado es para capital de trabajo para la compra de perfumes, cremas, ropa interior entre otros. Los sueños de Jenny son continuar mejorando su negocio y así lograr establecer un restaurante.
texts.en:
Jenny Elizabeth Alegría R. is 39 years old and married. She has 4 children. Her business is the sale of general merchandise, which she has done for more than 12 years. Doña Jenny began in the business through her aunt, who taught her the trade. It was through her aunt that she learned to enjoy the business, and through it to help maintain her family. Jenny intends to continue growing her business to strongly compete in the market. The loan she is requesting is for working capital, for the purchase of perfumes, creams and undergarments, among other things. Jenny's dream is to continue improving her business in order to someday establish a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Angelita is an industrious entrepreneur living with her family in a rural community located at Barangay Pieza Villaverde, Nueva Vicaya. Married to Benjamin G., she is a mother of six children. Two of her six children have already finished college, while four are still studying in high school and elementary. Angelita stresses that “patience is the key to success.” This principle keeps her focused on maintaining and growing her business. Moreover, it has guided her through hardships and difficulties in life. 

She is a vegetable vendor with a small stall in her village. She patiently maintains her business to earn an income and finance the studies of her children. Her husband cultivates their farm where they plant rice and vegetables. Angelita is hoping to borrow a loan from lenders amounting to PHP5,000 for her vending business. She hopes to increase the volume of her sales to generate a higher income and help all her children finish their studies in college.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia Gyesuwaa is a 56 year old mother of eight, all of whom are in school. She is very hard working and resourceful to her family. She trades in charcoal and fresh tomatoes in her neighborhood. Charcoal is very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes. Afia obtains her supply of charcoal from the surrounding villages of Dorma and retails them to her customers. 

She would like a loan to buy a bulk supply of charcoal to increase her inventory. This would enable her to increase her savings to pay for her children educational fees. She is grateful for your assistance. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Yewoha Nhyira’ which means Jehovah’s Blessing.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of charcoal

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Humans naturally have ambitions in life. Just like Annie, who is currently managing a general store in the village of Pieza VillaverD. of Nueva Vizcaya. She is hoping to someday become a successful entrepreneur. She is married to Rolando D. L. and they live peacefully and simply. They are striving to earn a larger income for the future of their family.

Annie is asking to borrow PHP 5,000 from the lenders. This money will immediately improve her business by increasing and diversifying her merchandise. She believes that her business will expand with this financial assistance and with her patience to manage her business well.

loans.use: To diversify merchandise

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary T. is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to provide her kids with quality education for their future careers. But she knows that without adequate funds it won't be possible to realize that dream. She is 45 years old and married with five kids who are currently in school.They live in Dorma Ahenkro in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She sells food like bags of maize, plantain and cassava in the local market.

Mary is humbly requesting your help to make her dream come true. She needs a loan so that she will be better resourced to take care of her children. With the loan, she wants to increase her stock of maize, plantain, cassava and charcoal by purchasing directly from the farmers to satisfy her customers’ needs. This will enable her to save more to support her husband in taking care of the home. She belongs to a village bank called Yewoha Nhyira which means Jehovah’s Blessing.

loans.use: To purchase cassava, charcoal, plantain and maize in bulk

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: Ana María B. D. tiene la edad de 50 años, su estado civil es casada. Doña Ana tiene 4 hijos y todos estudian. La actividad económica es pulpería hace mas de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio. Doña Ana inicio este negocio por cuenta propia, ya que tenia que hacerse cargo de su familia. Los propósitos de Ana son de mantener activo este negocio. El dinero que solicita es para capital de trabajo ya si comprar mas productos a mejores precios. Los sueños de Ana son de ampliar su negocio ya que este el único medio de supervivencia que ella posee.
texts.en:
Ana María B. D. is 50 years old and married. She has 4 children in school. Her business is a bodega, which she has run for more than 10 years. Doña Ana began the business on her own, since she had to take care of her family. She intends to keep the business active. She is requesting a loan for working capital, to purchase more products at better prices. Ana's dream is to increase her business, since it is her only means of survival.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marie Charmaine

texts.en:
Marie Charmaine M. is a young mother; she was only 16 years old when she married Edwin M.. They now have a two-year-old daughter named Paula Marie. They live in the rural village of Barangay Pieza Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. Since she was not able to pursue a college education because of early marriage, Charmaine has decided to establish a simple store to generate daily income for her family. The couple has a hard struggle with difficulties in their life and Charmaine is troubled with regrets sometimes but she is facing her choices in life and patiently doing her best to improve her lot.

Charmaine is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 to develop her store into a convenient and progressive business. Her husband operates a tricycle transport business from their home in order to have extra income aside from farming. The couple keeps holding onto their promise: “for richer and for poorer, till death do they part.” She will be very thankful if her loan is approved soon so she can improve her business and support her family more.

loans.use: To invest in a store

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en:
Bertha O. is a 37-year-old woman. She is married and the mother of three who are currently in school. Through hard work Bertha provide support for her children's education. She is a food vendor who has been selling banku and fufu in her neighborhood for the past two years now. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and taken with hot pepper, gravy stew or any kind of soup and fried fish or meat. Fufu is obtained from pounded cassava with plantains taken with hot soup, together with meat and fish.

Bertha has many customers since many Ghanaians enjoy banku and fufu as breakfast, lunch, and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, cassava, plantains, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. As a part of her business expansion, Bertha has added cooked rice and stew to her product line, and when asked she said most of her customers request the rice, so she saw it as an opportunity. She hopes to raise more income to help her husband take care of the children's educational needs. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Unity’.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Living in the midst of crisis is very difficult, said Editha. Especially if you have a family depending on you, yet have no stable job. Editha is married to Raul, a micro entrepreneur; she sells vegetables in their village of Pieza Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya, a rural and peaceful place. They are both high school graduates and very unfortunate, lacking enough income to support their family needs.

Editha is asking for loan amounting to PHP 5,000 that will served as additional working capital for her vending business in their village so that she can somehow improve her business and will someday have a vending stall in their public market. Finally, Editha said that being part of this lending program will someday pave their way to becoming progressive. Just be patient always and hard working, ended Editha.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance K. is 30 years old; she is married and mother of one child. Currently her child is in school. She lives at Dorma in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She is a petty trader who deals in assorted products like cooking utensils and plastic bowls, lunch boxes, etc. She mostly sells through hawking, that is, house to house selling. She has been in business for two years and two months now. With her humorous behavior, she has attracted lots of customers who purchase from her. She has decided to add eggs to her inventory which she supplies to food vendors in the evening.

Constance treks to Accra to purchase her stock of goods (cooking utensils). Recently she has been facing challenges in her business as a result of inadequate funds to buy stock. She requests a loan to buy more products like cooking utensils and crates of eggs etc. ,which are frequently demanded by her numerous customers. With the loan she believes she will be more resourced to make lots of profits to build a store to reduce the frequent walking in the street to sell. She would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to a village bank called ‘Unity’.

loans.use: to increase her stock of items such as cooking utensils and crates of eggs

loans.name: Soutien Plus Group

texts.fr: Godeline F. vend des poissons salés, des arachides, des pains et des fruits selon les saisons. Elle a commencé le commerce en vendant des pains en 1981 avec un capital initial de $3. De 1981 en 1990, l’évolution de son activité lui a permis de la diversifier en y ajoutant des savons, du sucre et des poissons salés. Les instabilités politiques et économiques des années 90 dans le pays ont également affaibli son activité. De 2000 à ce jour, Godeline a fournit un grand effort pour stabiliser son affaire. Elle a décidé d’intégrer un des groupes de Hope dénommé « Soutient » en vue d’avoir un appui financier pour développer son commerce en vue de supporter sa famille. Elle a planifié avec le crédit de mai courant d’acheter 1sac d’arachides et ½ carton des poissons salés à revendre dans le but d’accroitre le revenu. Son mari est tombé malade depuis 2005 et il est affaibli. Son ambition est d’ouvrir une maison des vivres frais. Son affaire lui procure un bénéfice de $120 par mois. Godeline est mariée et mère de 7 enfants dont leurs âges varient entre 13 et 28 ans. Six d’entre eux étudient.
texts.en:
Godeline F. sells dried fish, peanuts, bread, and fruits, depending on the season. She started her business by selling bread in 1981, with an initial capital of $3. From 1981 to 1990, the evolution of her business enabled her to diversify, adding the sale of soaps, sugar, and dried fish. Political and economical instabilities in the country during the 90's weakened her business. Since 2000, Godeline has been making great efforts to stabilize her business. She decided to join one of the groups of Kiva's partner, HOPE, in order to get financial support to develop her business to support her family. The group she joined is called "Soutient". She plans to use this loan to buy one sack of peanuts and one half box of dried fish, to retail in order to increase her revenue. Her husband has been sick and weak since 2005. Her ambition is to open a shop to sell fresh food. Her business turns a monthly profit of $120. Godeline is married and the mother of 7 children, who are between 13 and 28 years old. Six of them are students.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy one sack of peanuts and one half box of dried fish

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a 50-year-old mother of seven children who are schooling. She is very hard-working and resourceful to her family. She trades in firewood in her neighborhood. Firewood is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes, but it is mostly used buy those who produce food in larger quantities.

Elizabeth obtains her supply of firewood from the surrounding villages of Dorma and retails it to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply of firewood to increase her inventory. She hopes the loan will enable her to increase savings to pay her children's education fees. She would be grateful for your assistance and belongs to a village bank called ‘Unity’.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of charcoal.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
“No one can reach the top without taking a single step,” said Elsie, a business woman. She has engaged in a small business in order to assist her husband in supporting the needs of their family. She dreams that someday, they will become successful in life through hard work and patience. They have two children who are both attending elementary school. She is hoping that they may able to provide them with a good education for their future.

Her husband is working as a welder in Barangay Inaban, Dupax del Norte while Elsie is engaged in vegetable vending and selling some snacks. She is now requesting to take out a loan amounting to PHP 8,000 as additional capital for her business. She works hard and always prays that someday, she will become successful in the business which is very beneficial to their family, especially in sending her children to school. She will use the loan to buy more products for she believes that “the more products to sell daily, the higher the income generated”.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Xiomara Zulema

texts.es: Xiomara Zulema H. D. M. D. 26 años D. edad  resiD. en Apopa junto a su esposo y dos hijas D. 9 y un año y medio D. edad. Xiomara trabaja transportando estudiantes D. diferentes colegios en su propio microbús, ella es una mujer muy querida y respetado por los niños que transporta, y esto le incentiva a seguir adelante con su trabajo, ya que es por medio D. este como pueD. ayudar a su esposo a los gastos del hogar. Xiomara solicita un préstamo a través D. cual pueda comprar repuestos para su microbús y hacerle algunas reparaciones, con el fin D. brindar un servicio más seguro para los niños que viajan con ella.
texts.en:
Xiomara Zulema H. D. M., 26, lives in Apopa with her husband and two daughters ages nine and one and a half. Xiomara works transporting students from different schools in her own minibus. She is very loved and respected by the children she drives. This gives her the incentive to get ahead in her work. It is how she is able to help her husband with the household expenses. Xiomara is asking for a loan to buy replacement parts for her minibus and to make some repairs. She wants to do this to offer a safer service for the children who travel with her.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair her school minibus

location.town: Apopa en el departamento de San Salvador

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice A. is 40 years old, married and mother of three children. One is currently in school. Her husband is a farmer. She has been a food vendor for three years now. She prepares and sells rice and stew. It is a delicacy many Ghanaians enjoy every day either as breakfast, lunch or dinner. She also sells fried rice in the evening.

Beatrice's business is doing well and she wants to expand her operations to serve more customers. With the loan, she wants to buy more rice, vegetables and assorted meats for her operation. She hopes this loan will help her increase her savings to improve her family's well-being. She would be very grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘Nyame Nti’ which means "Christ's Sake".

loans.use: To buy bags of dried maize grains, rice, vegetables, assorted meats, etc.

loans.name: Emelyn

texts.en:
“I will do my best to achieve my goals in life,” says Emelyn D., a food vendor in a small vending stall in their simple village of Pieza Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Arellano, who is a very supportive husband. They work hard to earn a living for the sake of their two children who are presently studying in the secondary level of education.

Emelyn patiently manages her food vending business while her husband maintains their farm. She is asking to borrow loan from lenders the amount of PHP 5,000 as additional working capital in her livelihood project that is very saleable and generates a good income that supports their daily expenditures at home. She dreams that someday, she will able to improve her business through the financial assistance of lenders and through God’s grace.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. says; “If you have patience, you will survive.” This serves as her guiding principle in life. She is the loving wife of Danilo B. and they live happily in Barangay Aliaga Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. Through hard work and a lot of sacrifices, they have send their five children to school. Three of them are college graduates and presently working abroad, while two of them are already married after finishing their secondary education.

Their primary source of income is farming. Her husband cultivates their farm, while Erlinda manages their sound system and piggery businesses. She is able to generate an average monthly income of PHP 5,000 from their sound system service and also from their hog-raising sometimes. She plans to improve the business in order to earn more and save for their future. Hence, Erlinda wants to borrow the amount of PHP 5,000 as additional working capital for the maintenance of both her hog-raising and sound system businesses.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard B. is 59 years old; he is married and has three children. All his children are still in school. He lives with his wife who is a petty trader in the community where they live. They are currently living at Dorma Ahenkro, a farming community in the Brong Ahafo region in Ghana.

Bernard owns and operates grocery shop and sells items like sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, skimmed powdered milk and biscuits, etc. in his neighborhood. It has been his dream to expand by adding other foodstuffs to his existing products. With the loan, he wants to purchase more crates of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of biscuits, etc. to increase his inventory. He hopes to improve his savings to pay for his children's schooling. He belongs to the village bank called ‘Nyame Nti’ which means "Christ's Sake".

loans.use: To buy more cartons of assorted drinks, bags of sugar, cartons of bottled mineral water and boxes of biscuit etc.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
“Man is the architect of his own future,” is the quotation shared by Imelda D., which she learned from her friends. She realizes that this is true and has begun building her family’s future by patiently developing a sustainable business so that her family will not easily break down in times of life difficulties. Her family is happily living in the village of Pieza Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya. She has three children and has a good relationship with them and they are now attending elementary school.

Imelda is a soft drink dealer. She delivers soft drinks to stores in their village and nearby villages. The business is quite good and is generating average daily income. Imelda wants to improve her business further, so she wants to borrow from lenders the amount of PHP 5,000 as additional capital. She believes that someday her business will grow, and she will also diversify into other products through patience and the financial assistance of lenders.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine, or “Josie” as she is commonly known, is a resident of Barangay Inaban, Dupax del Norte of Nueva Vizacaya. She is the industrious wife of Ricardo Villoria. The couple aims to improve their standard of living and support the studies of their three children, especially now that they are about to enter college. They want them to finish their studies in college so that someday they will find good jobs.

Josie keeps on developing her general store as best she can, while her husband patiently cultivates their farm. Josie also sells vegetables. Since she is lacking working capital, she is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 to further develop her business and maintain a hog-raising business. She is hoping that with the financial support of lenders, she will increase her daily income to help her husband even more with their daily expenses and contribute to the education of their children.

loans.use: To invest in a store

loans.name: Erick Miguel

texts.es: Don Miguel es originario de la zona uno del departamento de Totonicapan su actividad principal es la creanza de pollo hoy necesita un credito para la construccion de un pequeño gallinero dicha actividad lo vienen realizando hace mas de 10 años cuenta actualmente  con cinco mil pollo ponedoras diariamente en la granja se recaudan aproximadamente tres Mil huevos y que son distribuidos en la diferentes tiendas de la localidad, con la construccion  estaran comprando mil pollo para poder cubri la demanda que se tiene por los clientes.
texts.en:
Miguel is a native of Zone One in the Totonicapan department. His primary activity is raising chickens. He now needs a loan to build a small hen house. He has been raising chickens for over ten years. He currently has five thousand laying hens. They collect approximately three thousand eggs daily. They are distributed to different stores in the area. With the construction, they will be buying a thousand chickens to be able to meet the customers’ demands.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials

loans.name: Etiennette

texts.fr:
K. Etiennette est née vers 1968 à Adja dans le Département du Mono au sud du Bénin. Etiennette est mariée et mère de quatre enfants. Les enfants de Etiennette sont encore à la charge des parents sauf un, qui lui est déjà majeur. Depuis près de cinq ans, Etiennette vend en gros le bois de chauffage. Etiennette a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits pour le compte de son activité. Etiennette sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé pour faire face à la demande de sa clientèle sans cesse croissante.  

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
Etiennette K. was born circa 1968 in Adja, in the Mono Department in Southern Benin. She's married and the mother of four children. One of her child is an adult already, but she still has to support the other three. For almost five years, Etiennette has been wholesaling firewood. She already obtained two loans for her business. She's seeking a third loan from Kiva's partner, Alidé, in order to meet an ever-increasing customer demand.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two truckloads of firewood

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 58-year-old married mother of eight children. Currently one of her children is in school and the rest are working. She is a petty trader who loves selling goods, the business that is her source of livelihood. Mary lives with her children in Dorma in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She has been selling foodstuffs like tubers of yam, maize, peppers, plantains and gari, etc., for 30 years now to support her family. She treks to farming communities like Techiman to buy her stock of food stuffs. Sometimes she spends days in the villages just to obtain large quantities of foodstuffs. This saves her from middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her with higher prices. With this loan, she wants to buy bulk tubers of yam, maize, peppers, onions, plantains, etc., to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids in school. Mary belongs to a village bank called "God First."

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs like yams, peanuts and beans etc.

loans.name: Ana Rosa

texts.es: Ana Rosa H. D. H. D. 49 años D. edad resiD. en Colón departamento D. La Libertad, vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como mecánico y no tiene hijos. Ana Rosa posee un comedor en la terminal D. buses, en el cual venD. tortillas bebidas, y comida, ella solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más jugos y sodas, así también más pan, D. manera que pueda surtir su negocio y tener mucho más que ofrecer a sus clientes, esperando obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Ana Rosa Hernandez Hernandez is 49 years old and resides in the state of Colon D. la libertad. She lives with her husband who works as a mechanic and has no children. Ana Rosa has a dining business in the bus station, where she sells tortillas drinks and food. She is asking for a loan in order to buy more juices, sodas, and bread, so she can have much more to offer to her customers and obtain higher profits.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of perishable goods

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
“Let us fight poverty,” says Lalila, who is doing her best to earn income in her vegetable-vending business and keep her family away from the hardships of life. Laila is an optimistic mother and loving housewife of Roberto U.; although the family is poor, they strive hard to earn income for their survival and for the future of their children. She has been encouraged by her neighbors in Inaban Dupax del Norte in Nueva Vizcaya to request a loan of PHP 8,000.

Currently earning an average weekly income of PHP 500, which is of great help in providing for some of the family’s basic necessities, Laila aspires to grow her business and become more successful. She hopes to improve their living conditions with the continuing support of Kiva and by believing in her own capacity to achieve her life goals.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a 48-year-old local restaurant operator. Her husband is teacher in the community where they live. They are blessed with eight children. With income from her business, she has provided for five of her children to graduate from high school.

In her restaurant, she prepares and sells local foods like fufu and banku. Fufu is prepared from pounded cassava and plantain and eaten with all kinds of soup. Banku is prepared from milled maize grains and is eaten with hot pepper or soup.

Rebecca says that the price of raw materials has gone up significantly and she needs the support of a loan to enable her to meet her production expenditures. She will use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. It is her desire to give her children hope and a better future. She belongs to the village bank called God First.

loans.use: To buy raw materials like bags of maize, baskets of cassava, plantain, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Angèle

texts.fr:
D. Angèle est née le 15 juillet 1972 à Ekpè, dans le Département de l'Ouéme. Angèle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Angèle vend des condiments de sauce devant son domicile au quartier Agblangandan à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Angèle achète ses provisions de sauce qu’elle revient revendre en face de sa maison. Angèle a déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits de la part de ALIDé pour développer son activité. Aujourd’hui encore, Angèle sollicite auprès de ALIDé un cinquième crédit pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
D. Angèle was born July 15, 1972 in Ekpè, in Ouéme County. Angèle is married and the mother of 3 children. She sells condiments for stew in front of her home in the Agblangandan neighborhood in Cotonou, economic capital of Bénin. Angèle buys her stock of condiments in Dantokpa, the big international market of Benin and re-sells them opposite her home. Angèle has already had four loans from ALIDé to develop her business. Today, Angèle is requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé so as to better satisfy her clientele.

The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Bénin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor." Bénin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria. Its per capita annual income stands at US$ 1,500.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 4 baskets of fresh tomatoes, 2 sacks of hot peppers, and 3 sacks of onions

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is now 46 years old. She has 4 children and they are living at Barangay Monguia, Dupax del Norte of Nueva Vizcaya. Despite being a widow, Leonida keeps doing her best to give her children a better future. She aims to be a good mother to them. She believes that nothing is impossible with God. Hence, she sacrifices a lot of her time to earn income and support the studies of her children who are now in high school.

She manages a general store to gain income for her family. She also maintains hog-raising business at the same time. Her children help her in managing both her store and hog-raising. Daily, Leonida is able to earn a net income of PHP 100, utilized to support the education of her children. Her family strives hard to overcome life's difficulties; she is thankful that she has learned about KIVA lending and is encouraged to join because of lack of financial capital. She is asking to borrow a loan amounting to PHP 15,000 for the improvement of her store and maintenance of her hog-raising business.

loans.use: Business Improvement

location.town: Monguia Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua M. is 52 years old. She is divorced and the mother of four children. Currently, two of them are in school. She loves selling goods, the business through which she obtains their daily source of livelihood. She has been selling bags of maize for ten years to support her family.

Maize is one of the favorite cereal grains that supply carbohydrate components in diets. She takes delivery of stock from farmers who provide her with direct supply. This enables her to avoid middlemen who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. With this loan, she wants to buy bulk supplies of maize to serve her customers. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids in school. She would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to a village bank called ‘God First’.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize

loans.name: Salifou

texts.fr:
D. Salifou est né le 01 AOUT 1985. Salifou est marié et père de deux (2) enfants tous scolarisés. Salifou a abandonné très tôt l’école pour se lancer dans le commerce des appareils électroniques. C’est au NIGERIA, État frontalier au Bénin que Salifou achète ses articles. Salifou a besoin de moyens financiers pour mieux répondre à la demande de  sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Salifou s’est rapproché de ALIDé pour faire un prêt. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
D. Salifou was born on August 1, 1985. Salifou is married and the father of 2 children, both in school. Salifou left school at a young age to begin selling electronic devices. He buys his merchandise in Nigeria, a country bordering Benin. He needs more working capital so as to be able to meet the needs of his clientele. That is the reason why Salifou has come to ALIDé to take out a loan.

The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Bénin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor." Bénin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria. Its per capita annual income stands at US$ 1,500.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 10 electronic devices, DVDs, and other electronic equipment

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
“I am dreaming to uplift my family out of poverty,” said Marilyn M., a street food vendor. She is a loving wife to Virgilio M.. They live in a rural community of Barangay Pieza Villaverde, Nueva Vizcaya with their three children who are studying in the secondary and elementary levels of education. Due to the prevalent economic crisis, this couple strives very hard to earn income in order to support the needs of their children, especially in sending them to school.

Marilyn is selling street foods in their village. Through the business, she is able to generate income for her family. She also sells different snacks like glutinous snacks, cooked sweet potato, cooked banana, etc. The majority of her weekly income which is around PHP 500 is utilized as allowances for her three children and she even saves some for their tuition fees. She is applying for a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional working capital for her current vending business.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Nasiatha

texts.en:
Nasiatha P. is a 59-year-old woman. She is widowed and the mother of six children. Through hard work Nasiatha has paid for three of them to complete senior high school, but the others are still schooling. Her husband died painfully through prolonged sickness. She was almost in tears when we were talking to her because she believes he has left so much responsibility on her.

She is a food vendor who sells kenkey in her neighborhood. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and taken with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaians enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch, and supper. Nasiatha wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to raise more income to support her children, especially for their education. She belongs to a village bank called ‘God First’.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Lokohounsi Gisèle

texts.fr:
H. Lokohounsi Gisèle est née vers 1968 à Ekpè, dans la Commune de Sèmè kpodji dans le Département de l’Ouémé. Lokossi Gisèle est mariée et mère de six (6) enfants. Lokohounsi Gisèle vend la nourriture au sein de la maternité de Ekpè au personnel de cette maternité et à ceux qui viennent aux soins . Lokohounsi Gisèle vend aussi des divers(Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, etc.). Avec la hausse actuelle du prix des denrées de première nécessité, Lokohounsi Gisèle a besoin de plus moyens financiers qu’elle n’en dispose. c’est pourquoi Lokohounsi Gisèle s’est approchée de ALIDé pour avoir un prêt afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle . 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
H. Lokohounsi Gisèle was born around 1968 in Ekpè in the township of Sèmè Kpodji in the County of Ouémé. She is married and the mother of 6 children. She sells food in the clinic for pregnant women in Ekpè to the staff of this facility and also to those who come in for care. She sells various items (candy, cookies, tins of milk, sardines and tomatoes; sugar, pasta, detergent, dish-washing liquid, and toilet soap) as well.

In view of the present price increases for staple goods, Lokohounsi Gisèle needs more capital than she has. That is why she has come to ALIDé to take out a loan so as to better satisfy her clientele.

. The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Bénin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor". Bénin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria, where the average per capita annual income stands at US$ 1,500.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 2 sacks of 50 kg of rice; tomatoes--both tinned and fresh; a case of tinned milk and powdered milk, and a case of detergent and dish liquid, a carton of lump sugar, and 50 kg of granulated sugar

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
After finishing her high school studies, Vilma got married to Victor A. and they live happily at Barangay Aliaga Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. They were blessed with four children. Three of them are now in their college education, therefore, they have to work hard to provide their children with their important needs.

They earn income thru farming as their major source of livelihood while Vilma manages a general store as an alternative source of income to support their daily needs. She is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 so that she will be able to expand her selling business further. She also hopes to improve her store by saving little amounts from her daily income. She believes that she will become successful in her business endeavor through patience and hard work.

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Adom

texts.en:
Adom Y. is a 46-year-old man. He is married, with four children who are currently in school. His wife is a petty trader who sells foodstuffs in the community where they live at Dorma. He is an agro-chemical seller and sells various kinds of chemicals like weedicides, fertilizers, pesticides, and spraying machines to the local farmers. He started this business two years ago.

Many local farmers patronize his products because of the current farming season where most farmers are actively preparing their farm lands. With the loan, Adom wants to purchase more supplies of weedicides, fertilizers, pesticides and spraying machines to serve the needs of his customers. He hopes to raise enough income to pay for his kids’ education. He would be very appreciative of your assistance. He belongs to a village bank called ‘God First’.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of weedicides, fertilizers, pesticides and spraying machines

loans.name: Odette

texts.fr:
K. Odette est née vers 1972 à Adjarra dans le Département de l'Ouémé. Odette vend des galettes d’arachide en gros et des sachets pour divers usages. C’est aux détaillants de galettes d’arachide du marché de Sèkandji dans la Commune de Sèmè-kpodji que Odette livre ses galettes. Odette achète ses galettes d’arachide à Bohicon dans le Département du ZOU. En ce qui concerne les sachets, Odette les achète au Nigeria, État frontalier au Bénin et les revend aux détaillants de ce produit à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Pour renforcer son fond de roulement afin de bien répondre à la demande de sa clientèle, sollicite de ALIDé un crédit. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
K. Odette was born around 1972 in Adjarra in the County of Ouémé. Odette sells peanut cookies wholesale and plastic bags for various usages. Odette delivers her peanut cookies to retailers at the market of Sèkandji in the township of Sèmè-kpodji. Odette buys her peanut cookies at Bohicon in the County of ZOU.

As for the bags, Odette buys them in Nigeria, a border state of Benin, and sells them to retailers of such products in Dantokpa, the big international market of Benin. To bolster her working capital so as to respond to the needs of her clientele, she is asking ALIDé for a loan.

The significance of ALIDé in the local language of Bénin, Fon, is "there is always a pathway for the poorest of the poor". Bénin is a small country in West Africa next door to Nigeria, where the average per capita annual income stands at US$ 1,500.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 4 big baskets of peanut cookies and 150 dozen bags

loans.name: Noor Jehan Liaqat Group

texts.en:
Jamila baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell.

Parveen baji wants a loan to buy items (chairs, mirrors and scissors) for her barber shop.

Shamim baji and another Shamim baji each want a loan to buy seasonal fruit to sell.

Noor Jehan baji is the group leader for these above-mentioned four ladies. They all live in an historic place in the city of Lahore named Yadgar, Pakistan. They all are very good natured ladies and very supportive also. Noor Jehan baji is married to Mr. L. who runs a fruit-selling business. He sells his products on a cart by calling out. She helps her husband by arranging the fruits on the cart which makes it easy for him to call out their names. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her husband's fruit-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruit to sell

loans.name: Abibata

texts.en:
Abibata is 40 years old; she is married and mother of three children. All her children are in school. She sells ladies' used footwear like slippers, sandals, shoes and sometimes school bags. Abibata has been in business for the last four years. She sells her products through hawking; she normally treks to sell in villages during their market days. Her husband sells agro chemical but does not have enough money to support his wife.

Abibata needs the loan to enable her to inject more working capital into the business to scale up business progress. She believes the loan will help her to be more resourced to purchase good quality and large quantity to upgrade her inventory. With the loan, she wants to purchase assorted used shoes, sandals and slippers in bulk. She would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank called ‘God first’.

loans.use: To purchase used shoes, slippers, and sandals, etc.

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en:
Christopher is already 30 years old and a resident of Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela. He is married to Juliet F., 33 years old, who is currently working as a domestic helper abroad. They have a son; his name is Christian James, already 9 years old and attending primary school.

Christopher is engaged in the transportation business. He operates a passenger tricycle and he is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 6,000. He needs money to pay the monthly amortization of his motorbike. He is only earning an income of PHP 200 every day. He lets his wife work in another country because they really have a problem when it comes to financial matters. They also want to save for the future schooling of their son. Christopher and his wife have lots of dreams, that is why they are doing everything to achieve their dreams.

loans.use: Financial Assistance

loans.name: Ambrosio Irineo

texts.es:
El joven padre de familia señor Ambrosio vive con su esposa  y tres hijos de edad pequeña, el labora para una empresa desde hace tres años como supervisor de línea, obteniendo un muy buen ingreso, su esposa la señora Juanita es enfermera de una maquiladora contando con una antigüedad de 2 años. 
Ellos han ido realizando un proyecto que tienen, el cual es ampliar su vivienda mediante la construcción de un cuarto para mayor comodidad de la familia, pero les esta haciendo falta los acabados exteriores e interiores del cuarto en construcción. Motivo por el cual están solicitando este crédito.
texts.en:
Ambrosio, a young father, lives with his wife and three small children. He has worked for a company as a line supervisor for three years. He gets a very good income. His wife, Juanita, is a nurse in a factory. She has been doing this for two years. They are working on a project to expand their house by building a room to make the family more comfortable. However, they are lacking the exterior and interior finishings for the room under construction. That is why they are asking for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Interior and exterior finishings

loans.name: Darius

texts.en:
Darius is only 24 years old, but he is already married to Ashley and they already have one child named Darvie Miacheal, now 3 years old. They reside in an urban area of Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela. Darius is very happy and proud to have a family that is peaceful and loving. He is praying that this kind of relationship in their family will remain the same for the years to come. He is also grateful for having his wife who is very supportive and is always helping him improve their market vending business. According to Darius, he will do everything he can to succeed in life as long as he has the strength to do so for the welfare of his family. Go confidently in the direction of your dreams, live the life you imagined, he adds.

Darius is requesting a loan from lenders amounting to PHP 6,000 as additional working capital to his small snack vending stall in the market. Darius, together with his wife, is selling cooked snacks such as “pansit”, banana-cue, juices, soft drinks, etc. He is hoping for his business to grow by working diligently so he can also uplift his family's way of living. He is planning to save some of his income for the future schooling of his son and future children.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Taïba

texts.fr:
S. Taïba est de nationalité béninoise et est née vers 1977. Taïba est mariée et mère de deux enfants. Taïba vend devant sa maison la bouillie de maïs accompagnée de beignets faits à base de farine de blé. Le maïs a doublé de prix et le prix de la farine de blé a aussi grimpé. Les moyens financiers dont dispose Taïba ne lui permet de s’approvisionner suffisamment en maïs et farine de blé. C’est pourquoi Taïba sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé pour soutenu son activité. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500.
texts.en:
S. Taïba is a Beninese national born around 1977. She is married and the mother of two. She sells porridge in front of her house and serves with it beignets made of wheat flour. Corn has doubled in price, and the price of flour has also been climbing. The financial means available to her doesn't allow her to stock up sufficiently with corn and wheat flour. This is why she's requesting a loan from ALIDÉ, so as to support her business. ALIDÉ means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 50-kg sacks of corn, a 50-kg sack of wheat flour, a 50-kg sack of sugar, and a 25-liter drum of peanut oil

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena was engaged in a vending business located in their town public market of Ilagan, Isabela. in the market, she sells onions, garlic, vegetables, some cooked snacks, etc. Lucena is requesting a loan as working capital for her vending business. According to her, the loan will be of great help to grow her business because she could have more products to sell. Her children, who are already married, are not living with her but she is the one sending her granddaughter to school. She hopes that she will have more income so that she could provide forthe needs of her family and grandchildren if they need her support.

Lucena is already 50 years old. She resides in Barangay Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela, and a place where the old supermarket of Ilagan was situated before. She was married to Andres P. who is a tricycle operator. They are blessed with three childen who were now married, and she has grandchildren.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Jaime

texts.es:
El señor Jaime vive con la señora Juanita G. Rayas, juntos tienen su estética negocio propio que establecieron desde hace 11 años y aparte una Institución de Belleza nombrada “Nefertiti”, su negocio esta muy bien establecido,cuentan con clientela y con alumnas que ellos están capacitando para ser futuras estilistas. 
El motivo por el cual ellos están solicitando este crédito es para la compra de más mercancía y el pago a proveedores, para seguirle dando la mejor atención a sus clientes, con mayor comodidad y la mejor calidad en belleza.
texts.en:
Jaime lives with Mrs. Juanita G. Rayas. They have their own salon, which they have been working at for the past 11 years. In addition to the salon, they also run the "Nefertiti Beauty Institute." Their business is very well-established; they have regular clients and also train students to be stylists. They are requesting this loan so that they can buy more merchandise and pay their providers in order to better serve their customers with great comfort and high-quality beauty services.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more merchandise, pay providers

loans.name: Samina Khalid Javed Group

texts.en:
Riaz baji wants a loan to buy goats for her animal selling business.

Gulshan baji and Zakia baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.

Ruqaiya baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to resell.

Samina baji is a group leader of the above mentioned ladies. They all are a citizens of a historical place of the city Lahore named Yadgar, Pakistan. These ladies belong to a poor family, but they have no regrets about that. They are spending their lives in a happy way. They take care of their families, and their family members respect them alot. Samina baji is married to a man who is a butcher by profession and runs a butcher shop in the community. He sells red meat (goat & buffalo) on customer demand. He is a good-natured person; thats why people are attracted to his shop to buy meat. Samina baji is applying for a loan to buy goats for her husband's butcher shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals (goats) for butcher shop

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr: C. Chantal est née le 14 Avril 1971 à Comè, dans le Département du Mono. Chantal est semi-grossiste dans la vente des produits de brasserie. Chantal vend les casiers de boissons de la Société Béninoise de Brasserie (SOBEBRA). Chantal vend aussi les divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, etc.). C’est dans sa boutique construite devant sa maison que Chantal vend ses produits. Chantal a utilisé tous ses revenus pour soigner son mari qui était malade. Cet événement malheureux a beaucoup influencé l’activité de Chantal. Chantal a donc besoin de moyens financiers pour soutenir son activité. C’est pourquoi Chantal sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
C. Chantal was born on April 14, 1971 in Comè, in Mono County. She is a semi-wholesaler selling brewery products. She sells cases of beverages from the Société Béninoise de Brasserie (SOBEBRA). Chantal also sell various goods: candy, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardines, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, etc. Her shop, set up in front of her house, is where she sells her goods. She has used all of her income to take care of her husband, who is ill. This unhappy event has greatly affected her business. She therefore has need of financing to support her business. This is why she's requesting a loan from ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 30 cases of brewery drinks, a box of canned milk, a box of canned tomatoes, two boxes of laundry and dish soaps, five 5-kg sacks of Gino rice, and two boxes of pasta.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.es:
La Sra. Marcelina A. de 37 años de edad, está casada con el Sr. Antonio Escobar de 35 años de edad, ellos tienen 2 hijos que están cursando sus estudios secundarios.
    Doña Marcelina tiene una despensa bien surtida, ha empezado este negocio con el capital obtenido con el trabajo y esfuerzo de su esposo, que es oficial de obras, aproximadamente en el año 1.990; en la actualidad la mayoría en la comunidad son sus clientes ya que ofrece cordial atención.
   Ella invertiría este crédito para la comprar un terreno que está pegado a su vivienda para poder construir ahí el salón para su negocio, ya que actualmente lo tiene en su propia casa y no hay espacio suficiente. 
   Y espera que esta crisis se normalice lo antes posible, para que tengamos más fuente de trabajo.
texts.en:
Ms. Marcelina A. is 37 years old, and is married to Mr. Antonio Escobar who is 35 years old. They have 2 sons who are attending high school. Ms. Marcelina has a well-stocked pantry shop. She started this business about 1990 with her husband’s savings from years of work and effort, he is a foreman.

Since she offers cordial service, most of the community is currently her customer. She has not enough space to keep the business at her house so she will invest the money from this loan to buy a land that is located next to her house and then to build and establish her business there. She hopes this crisis will normalize as quickly as possible so there will be more work sources.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a land.

loans.name: Margie

texts.en:
Margie is now 45 years old. She is residing in the urban area of Calamagui 1st Ilagan, Isabela. She is married to Yollie J., 43 years old. Her husband is helping in their vending business. They are blessed with a son who is Yolmar, 12 years old, attending elementary school. Margie is engaged in selling seasoning products such as onions, garlic, vegetable, etc. She is requesting a loan to have her business grow. She is planning to purchase more products to sell to have sufficient supply of vending products to be able increase her income. 

Margie is dreaming that her son could also finish his studies and have a good future someday, and to able achieve this, she must therefore work patiently no matter how hard life is. Finally, Margie shared that “You see things and say, 'why?", but “I dream things and say, 'Why not?” Indeed, every dream that we have right now, could someday become real through our own ways and deeds, pursuing the right decisions we desire to do.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Abiba

texts.fr: Y. Abiba est née vers les années 1982 au Nord du BENIN. Abiba est célibataire  sans enfant. Abiba est issue d'une famille très pauvre. Abiba est venue à Cotonou,  Capitale Économique du Bénin  pour  chercher de l’argent. C’est ainsi que s’est lancée dans la restauration populaire. Vend de couscous fait à base de tubercule de manioc appelé localement achèkè. Pour soutenir son activité Abiba a besoin de moyens financiers. C’est pourquoi Abiba sollicite un prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Y. Abiba was born around 1982 in northern Benin. She is unmarried and has no children. Abiba is from a very poor family. She has come to Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, in search of money, so she got started in basic food catering, selling a couscous made from cassava tubers called achèkè locally. To support her business, she has need of funding. This is why she's requesting a loan from ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy five sacks of cassava tubers, a box of fresh fish, and a 25-liter drum of peanut oil

loans.name: Nila

texts.en:
Nila is a mother of three children, and with her goal to pursue the education of her children, she tries to bring out her best in developing her business in order to earn higher income. They live in San Manuel, Isabela, and her husband is Reynaldo.

She owns and operates a small store in their village. She is really working hard to become successful in the future.  And for her to achieve this, she would like to borrow a loan so that she can use it as additional business capital for her store.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es: Teresa D. Jesús E. L. D. V. resiD. en Santa Tecla junto a su única hija D. 19 años D. edad, la cual se encarga D. todos los quehaceres del hogar. Teresa D. Jesús posee una venta D. cosméticos como champo, talcos, desodorantes, cremas para el cabello entre otros productos más. Su negocio está ubicado frente al parque San Martín D. Santa Tecla, un lugar muy transitado lo cual beneficia a Teresa. Ella solicita un préstamo con el fin D. poder comprar más cosméticos para su negocio, ya que este es muy importante para ella debido a que es la única fuente D. ingresos que posee.
texts.en:
Teresa D. Jesús E. L. D. V. lives in Santa Tecla together with her only daughter, who is 19 years old and is in charge of all of the household chores. Teresa D. Jesús has a business selling cosmetics such as shampoo, talcum powder, deodorant, hair cream and other such products. Her business is located opposite the San Martín D. Santa Tecla Park, a well-travelled location which is to Teresa's advantage. She is requesting a loan with the objective of being able to buy more cosmetics for her business, which is very important to her since it is the sole source of income that she has.
